Some restaurants and servers in the state might start taking a harder look at IDs when serving alcohol PERIOD

A bill which is now in the Virginia General Assembly would make it a misdemeanor crime for individuals such as store clerks and waiters to not ask for identification when serving alcohol PERIOD

The bill has passed the House of Delegates and the Senate Courts of Justice Committee approved it on Friday PERIOD To become a law it must be approved by the Senate overall and then signed by the governor PERIOD

The bill is aimed to make the individual server responsible for checking IDs instead of just the businesses that are selling the alcohol PERIOD

Currently if a business or individual sells alcohol to someone they have reason to believe is under  they could be charged with a class one misdemeanor and face up to one year in prison and a  fine PERIOD This law would increase the crime to a class three misdemeanor for failing to check an ID altogether PERIOD

Chris Head RBotetourt County introduced the bill after the Roanoke Area Youth Substance Abuse Coalition approached him regarding the issue PERIOD If passed the offense would carry a maximum penalty of  PERIOD

Kathy Graham Sullivan RAYSAC director said that although it may seem like the bill is meant to affect college towns its not targeted at any specific population PERIOD

Its a community effort to reduce underage drinking Sullivan said PERIOD The bill puts the burden of proof back on the servers or the clerk.That wont be happening any moreThey cant.I understand the reasoning behind the bill but I feel like if underage teens want to drink they will find others ways to obtain alcohol he said PERIOD
